Erik Hetzner wrote:
> At Thu, 20 Nov 2008 20:01:07 +0000,
> Mike Kelly <mike@...> wrote:
>   
>> Maybe - I see browsers as a special case that are responsible for
>> handling many different content-types depending on context rather
>> than most UAs which have a fixed order of preference.
>>
>> The User-Agent header and/or a fixed Accept header would be
>> sufficient for most UA's, however there are cases where it is
>> desirable to change the Accept header to reflect the context of a
>> hyperlink in the HTML GUI of your application.
>>     
>
> The Accept header is really the client’s business, not the server’s.
> If you want to change the ‘context’, then change the URI.
>
>   
http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html

"The Accept request-header field can be used to specify certain media 
types which are acceptable for the response. Accept headers can be used 
to indicate that the request is specifically limited to a small set of 
desired types, as in the case of a request for an in-line image."

Am I missing something?

>> I'm aware that content negotiation is possible by effectively moving
>> it into the URI. But is this necessary or desirable if the markup
>> provisions HTTP conneg? I'm not sure.
>>
>> One thing that bothers me about using the URIs for that, is it
>> becomes unclear whether a PUT to /document.pdf is an update that
>> will be reflected in /document.doc and /document.xml - this is
>> requiring the users, and caching mechanisms to be application aware.
>>     

Does anyone have any comments on this?

Regards,
Mike
